content: Hey, I've been working on #60302, however lately I've been somewhat swamped with uni work and regular work. I've got some changes I've made that have been working towards completing this, however, there is still a lot of work to go. I'd like to keep working on this, but it could take me a while, would this be a decent case where I could create a pull request, get the work I've already done looked at (and hopefully merged) and continue working on the rest of issue, or would the team prefer that I either, step away from the issue and let someone with the time to look at it take over, or I continue working on it when I can?
If you have something partway done absolutely feel free to open a PR :)
That avoids people trying to work on it concurrently without knowing too
Fantastic. I'll create a PR now. Hopefully I do it all right :grimacing:
But if you do something different it's fine, that's what review is for :)
Oooh, okay, should have read that section way sooner. I have a merge commit. Is there a way to fix that with Git, or will I need to do something else?
(I've also been bitten by this before, why aren't merge commits allowed anyway?)

I've read elsewhere that they make the commit history messy. This is my first open source project, so normally in my own projects, this kind of thing hasn't been an issue. I just wasn't thinking about it when I was working on this.
Merge commits make an historic non-linear, which is viewed as messy since it makes it harder to search for bugs with git bisect for example

As a note, when I was looking for info about how to structure my PR, I checked out the "A typical contribution" section of the Guide to Rustc development book, because based on the available sections, that seemed the most likely. I wouldn't have thought to look in the Coding Conventions sections (I wouldn't consider a PR a piece of code is why I'm guessing)

Merge commits make an historic non-linear,

Note that history will already be non-linear as there are multiple branches happening concurrently anyway. Removing merge commits _reduces_ the non-linearity though.
